title: How to Count to Ten in Tagalog

steps.title: Tatlo (Three) is pronounced as "tat-lo."
steps.content: Tatlo (Three) is pronounced as "tat-lo." [1] X Research source

steps.title: Apat (Four) is pronounced as "ah-pat."[2] X Research source
steps.content: Apat (Four) is pronounced as "ah-pat." [2] X Research source

steps.title: Lima (Five) is pronounced as "lih-ma."[3] X Research source
steps.content: Lima (Five) is pronounced as "lih-ma." [3] X Research source

steps.title: Anim (Six) is pronounced as "ah-nim."[4] X Research source
steps.content: Anim (Six) is pronounced as "ah-nim." [4] X Research source

steps.title: Pito (Seven) is pronounced as "pi-to."[5] X Research source

steps.title: Walo (Eight) is pronounced as "wah-lo."[6] X Research source

steps.title: Siyam (Nine) is pronounced as "see-yam."
steps.content: Siyam (Nine) is pronounced as "see-yam." [7] X Research source

steps.title: Sampû (Ten) is pronounced as "sam-pu.[8] X Research source
